a.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability of critical infrastructure.  Those have been divided in two different categories: 4 (private school, UPS, childcare, public school)  and 5 (Airport,  Amtrak,  police, fire station, hospital).

b.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the population with disability. The number of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

d.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability of buildings. The area occupied by buildings in each square of the grid has been divided in different categories, ranking from 2 (less vulnerable) to 4 (most vulnerable).

e.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the population with minor age. The number of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

f.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the population density. The number of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

g.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability due to streets elevation. Streets have been divided in five different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

h.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given due to land elevation. The number of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

i.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the population with health insurance. The number of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

j.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability of Erosion Susceptibility.  It has been divided in different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

k.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by coastal structure (CS). The biggest CS (area) in the features is described in the field ATRIBUTE and SUBCLASS. It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 4 (most vulnerable). If the feature does not have rank coastal structure, rank is zero and ATRIBUTE and SUBCLASS are empty.

l.abstract: This composite layer reflects the vulnerability of Connecticut's habitat, including data about forests, hydrology, eelgrass, and 'critical habitat.'

m.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability due to the proportion of seniors in the population. The proportions of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

n.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability due the salt water limits. It has been divided in two categories, ranking from zero (less vulnerable, above the salt water limit) to five (most vulnerable, under the salt water limit).

o.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the combination of critical infrastructure, coastal structure and buildings. The rank is the mean between the maximum rank of critical infrastructure and building and the rank of coastal structure. It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 4 (most vulnerable). If the feature does not have rank coastal structure, rank is zero.

p.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the population income. The number of people have been divided in five categories: ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

q.abstract: This data table defines the coastal vulnerability based on surficial aquifer potential of Connecticut Coastal Cities. Surficial materials have been divided in different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

s.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by storms. Storms vulnerability have been divided in different categories, ranking from 1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

u.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability of Aquifers. Aquifer protection areas have been divided in different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

v.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given by the distance from I95 exits. Streets have been divided in five different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

w.abstract: This data table defines the coastal vulnerability based on surficial material of Connecticut Coastal Cities. Surficial materials have been divided in different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

x.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability based on the wind speed at 30(m).  It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

y.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability based on the wave power index.  It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

ab.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability given hydrology structure. The presence of hydrology structures in each features are described in the field name. It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable). If the feature does not have hydrology structure rank is zero and name is empty.

bb.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability based on the presence of Submerged Cable and Pipeline Areas.  It has been divided in two different categories, presence (rank 5) or absence (rank 0) of cable/submerged pipelines.

db.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability due to Erosion Rate. It has been divided in different categories, ranking from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

eb.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability based on Soil Drainage. It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

fb.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability based on the soil flooding class.  It has been divided in different categories, ranking from1 (less vulnerable) to 5 (most vulnerable).

ib.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability of slope. Slope has been divided in five different categories, from one (less vulnerable) to five (most vulnerable).

jb.abstract: This data table defines the Connecticut coastal vulnerability due to impervious surface. Those have been divided in two categories: 1 (less vulnerable) and 5 (most vulnerable).

kb.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: Hydrology, Habitat and Sea Level Rise.

lb.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: Amtrak Stations, Building, Critical Infrastructure, Coastal Structure, Pipeline and Submerged Cables, Streets, Proximity to I95 and Sea Level Rise.

mb.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: Disable Population, Employed Population, Health Insurance, Young Population, Elderly Population, Population Density and Sea Level Rise.

ob.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: Disabled Population, Employed Population, Health Insurance, Young Population, Elderly Population, Population Density and Sea Level Rise.

pb.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: Disabled Population, Employed Population, Health Insurance, Young Population, Elderly Population, Population Density and Sea Level Rise.

qb.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: sea level rise, wave power, storm surge, tide and wind speed at 10(m).

rb.abstract: This data table is the geometric mean computed using the following input layers: elevation, slope, soil flooding, soil drainage, habitat, erosion rate, erosion susceptibility and impervious surfaces.
